The Neolithic Revolution, also known as the Agricultural Revolution or the First Agricultural Revolution, was a major turning point in human history. It took place between approximately 10,000-8,000 BCE and marked the transition from hunter-gatherer societies to settled farming communities. During this period, humans began to develop agriculture systematically: cultivating plants for food and domesticating animals.

Some key changes during the Neolithic Revolution include:

1. Settled lifestyle - People moved away from nomadic hunting and gathering groups towards establishing permanent settlements centered around farming communities.

2. Agriculture - The cultivation of crops like wheat, barley, peas, lentils and other early plant species started on a large scale. Seasonal planting cycles allowed people to produce food all year round.
